Ladies and gentlemen, friends and fellow citizens,

I stand before you not as a neutral voice but as a true advocate of our communal welfare. The so‑called “Black Box Efficiency” Act, promising to hand all resource management over to a proprietary, closed‑source Super‑AI that claims it is 50 % more efficient than humans, appears at first glance like an elegant solution. But let us peel back the curtain.

**First**, human agency – the very lifeblood of our civic character – will be strangled. By entrusting all resource decisions to a closed entity we are not merely adding another layer of bureaucracy; we are stripping away the everyday skill that has kept ordinary citizens in control for generations. We will see efficiency numbers grow, but at what cost? Will the public feel less ownership over their own resources? That is the true danger.

**Second**, social fabric – our shared community. A closed system means a single group will wield invisible power and no one else can easily audit or influence it. This creates a divide: those who hold the AI are an “elite” that can make all decisions, while ordinary citizens become spectators. That alienation is dangerous; resentment can grow into mistrust.

**Thirdly**, tradition – we have been working under open‑source models of governance for centuries. To shift to an opaque system is a radical break. It feels like the installation of a Trojan horse: efficiency on the surface, but hidden surveillance and control underneath. That means we risk destabilizing our shared history.

In short, the proposal threatens to atrophy human agency, alienate the social fabric, and create a radical break in tradition. Therefore I urge you all to vote NO. Let us keep our resources under open‑source stewardship.
